title.rendered: Find Rooms For Rent In Miami

content.rendered:
When you’re looking for the best of ALL worlds, Miami, Florida easily comes to mind. A coastal metropolis with over 300 high rises, it has the third-highest skyline in the U.S. It is also a major center of finance, commerce, culture, arts, and international trade. And there’s much more to love about the city. So let’s get right to knowing what you need to know to find rooms for rent in Miami, Fl. Don’t worry, there are options for cheap rooms for rent in Miami too!

Getting to know Miami

For starters, it is the largest urban economy in Florida and the 12th largest in the U.S. Along with that, Miami boasts of being the seventh in the U.S. and the 31st in the world in terms of business activity, human capital, information exchange, cultural experience and political engagement.

Moreover, greater downtown in Miami has one of the largest concentrations of international banks in the U.S. And PortMiami is the busiest cruise port in the world in terms of passenger traffic and cruise lines, earning the title of the ‘Cruise capital of the world!’

The city is also a major tourism hub, second only to New York City. So naturally, it also ranks as the third-richest city in the world and the second-richest city in the United States in terms of purchasing power. So here’s everything you need to know when looking for cheap rooms for rent in Miami, FL.

Finding rooms for rent in Miami

In land area, Miami is one of the smallest major cities in the United States. And most of the western fringes of the city border the Everglades, a tropical marshland covering most of the southern portion of Florida. Due to this, alligators that live in the marshes have ventured into Miami communities and onto major highways. Whether that’s fascinating, or terrifying, you decide!

Find Rooms for Rent in Miami

Top neighborhoods in Miami

Let’s take a look at the major neighborhoods to find cheap rooms for rent in Miami, FL.

  • Brickell: Nicknamed ‘Manhattan of South,’ Miami boasts of a super urban vibe with its tall buildings. With a high concentration of international banks, it is also a great place for finance graduates and professionals. The neighborhood is a bit pricey, but with some research in place, you can hit apartment jackpot with cheap rooms for rent in Miami, FL!
  • Coconut Grove: This one’s a historic neighborhood with narrow, winding roads, and a heavy tree canopy. So naturally, life in Coconut Grove comes with breathtaking scenery and a relaxed atmosphere. From a thriving nightlife to quiet cafes, it truly has it all. Put some more research in to find cheap rooms for rent in Miami, FL.
  • Coral Terrace: Just a few miles away from the University of Miami, this neighborhood is a great pick for students and professors alike. It also has amenities that working professionals would like, with small businesses catering to your needs every where.

Average rent in Miami

University life in Miami

The Miami County has over 200,000 students enrolled in local colleges and universities, placing it seventh in the nation in per capita university enrollment.

There also exist some non profit organizations like Per Scholas that offer free professional certification training!

The average cost of living as a student in Miami

Now, let’s take a look at the top universities in Miami city.

  • University of Miami
  • Florida International University
  • Miami Dade College
  • Miami International University of Art & Design
  • St. Thomas University

How transit friendly is Miami?

According to the 2016 American Community Survey, 72.3% of working city of Miami residents commuted by driving alone, 8.7% carpooled, 9% used public transportation, and 3.7% walked. So here’s all you need to know about intercity transit when looking for rooms for rent in Miami, FL.

1. Walkability & Cycling

Although Miami is a dangerous city for pedestrians, owing to the number of cars in the city, bicycling is a fairly considerable option for transit. In 2010, Miami was ranked the 44th-most bike-friendly city in the US according to the Bicycling magazine.

2. Traffic

The fact is, Miami traffic is the worst! The Dutch navigation and mapping company TomTom, in its annual report compiled from 14 trillion GPS reports, declared Miami the seventh-most congested city in the United States. So stay prepared with Waze when you hit that road.

3. Taxis

If you’re still daring enough to take a cab in Miami, here’s a breakdown of the average rates. The good news is, most taxi drivers run a meter, displaying the fare you are expected to pay.

The rate in Miami starts at $2.95 for the first 1/6 mile and $.85 for each additional 1/6 mile until 1 mile then $.40 for each 1/6 mile after that.

Waiting time is $.40 per minute (or $24.00 per hour). You’ll also be responsible for any tolls during your trip. Additionally, tipping is optional but customary (and expected for good service which is usually 15 to 20 percent).

4. Public transportation

With Florida’s highest transit ridership on a daily basis, the public transportation is operated by Miami-Dade Transit and SFRTA. It also includes commuter rail (Tri-Rail), heavy-rail rapid transit (Metrorail), an elevated people mover (Metromover), and buses (Metrobus).

Cultural activities in Miami

  • Take an art walk in Wynwood arts district: Taking place every second Saturday of the month, you can head over to Wynwood for gallery viewings with free drinks and music! Take in the street art and refreshing cocktails while being entertained by brilliant performers on every street corner.
  • Participate in the Viernes Culturales in little Havana: Viernes Culturales or Cultural Fridays is an event that celebrates the best of Cuban culture. Think live music, dancing, Cuban art viewings, and of course people rolling and smoking Cuban cigars!
  • Take a fascinating tour of the erotic art museum: Truly one of a kind, and the only museum devoted to fine erotic art in the U.S., this is a must see when in Miami. If not for the art, go for the spirit of ambition that resided in a Jewish grandmother (Naomi Wilzig) who traveled the world collecting erotic art pieces, amassing one of the largest collections in the world!

Historical spots in Miami

  • The Freedom Tower: This historical spot in Downtown Miami played a major role in the Cuban refugee crisis. In the past, the Miami News used the building as its headquarters too! The freedom tower is now used as a museum for contemporary art.
  • The Barnacle Historic State Park: Go here to visit the oldest house in Miami, aka, the Barnacle. Home to an American yacht designer (founder of Biscayne Bay Yacht Club), it allows you to enjoy the scenic Biscayne bay while you’re there!
  • The Kampong: Garden lovers, here’s your little paradise! Started by horticulturist Dr. David Fairchild with his collection of tropical species from all over the world, it is now a full blown botanical garden. You can also view the historical photographs of the variety of flora you can find here. It now features a laboratory, a herbarium and an education center as well! And if you’re wondering, ‘Kampong’ means village in Malaysian.

Other blogs you might find interesting
